The hapy revival
 Rebeca Njuguna
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 For ages, Olokwango hil stod smiling at the midle of
 Kwere plains. From the two dimples on its side came springs
 
 which converged downhil to form a river. River Temu
 meandered silently acros the Kwere plains. Its waters were
 a gift to the shep and goats of the area as wel as the der
 
 that dwelt in the plains. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Things were al wel until Matata became headman. 
 He ordered a path to be cleared from the top of the hil to the 
 fot so that he could climb uphil easily and rol gently down 
 
 to the fot. Olokwango hil was angry with the damage to his 
 beard, but he was patient. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 During the wekend, Matata’s children and their friends
 would climb uphil to play. 
 They would run al over the place, breaking twigs and
 
 branches, lighting fires for their games, which they would
 later leave burning. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Over time, Olokwango lost patience. The dimples became 
 smaler and smaler as his face turned into ugly wrinkles. 
 
 
 At last the springs were no more. The der in the plains 
 migrated because there was no more the tal gren gras to 
 play in. The shep and goats grew thiner and thiner. 
 
 
 Everyone felt the sadnes of Olokwango hil. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The people of Kwere realized that something neded to be
 done. 
 They joined hands and overthrew Matata the headman.
 
 
 In his place they apointed Baraka who imediately ordered
 everyone to plant a flower to honour Olokwango. Baraka and
 
 his people held ceremonies and brought gifts of pine, cedar,
 and cypres for Olokwango. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 No one walked on the hil any longer, and the gras had a
 chance to grow tal once again. 
 
 
 Gradualy the smile on the face of Olokwango hil grew
 broader and the dimples deper. Out of the dimples the
 springs ran again. River Temu was rejuvenated. The plains
 
 became grener than ever before. The der galoped hapily
 once more acros the gras. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “Long live Baraka, long live Baraka,” the people of Kwere 
 
 sang. 
 “Long live, Olokwango,” said Baraka and his people. “May our 
 children and children’s children forever respect you.”
